table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to the sound, and not to any letter or glyph.

table.name: mem
table.column: Your mother has a smooth forehead!

table.name: mem
table.column: The onomatopoetic exclamations {HghHghHgh:sen:nolink} and {HghHgh:sen:nolink} are sometimes used for writing out laughter. There's some standardization, but also lots of variation and creativity.[2]
▶ {Hagh qoHpu' neH HeghtaHvIS SuvwI'pu'.:sen} ▶ {cheqotlhchugh maHaghbe''a'? cheDuQchugh mareghbe''a'? cheQIHchugh manoDbe''a'?:sen}

table.name: mem
table.column: Only fools laugh while warriors die.

table.name: mem
table.column:
The object is the thing being soaked or drenched.
{HaH'egh:v@@HaH:v:1, -'egh:v} is used to refer to drinking a great deal, or bathing.[1, p.91]

table.name: mem
table.column: This word is used by upper-class speakers for {gham:n} served as food.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is an animal found on {Qo'noS:n} that's sort of weasel-like.

{vav:n} "father", or colloquially "pop", and {jaH:v} "go" together make "pop goes the weasel".
The request was for a musteloid (otter-like or wolverine-like animal).

table.name: mem
table.column: Sugar is not a native Klingon thing. Klingon {Halrov:n:nolink}, made by boiling the stems of a particular plant (and then doing some other things), is a thick, sticky, gooey liquid, but it's not sweet. If specificity is needed, one can say {Su'ghar Halrov:n:nolink} or {Su'ghar qut Halrov:n@@Su'ghar qut:n, Halrov:n} for the Terran concoction.[1]
The word "treacle" was used in Middle English to describe a medicine believed to be an antidote which can cure ({vorlaH:sen@@vor:v, -laH:v}) poisons, snakebites, and other ills.

table.name: mem
table.column: This might refer to a high voice, or a high note in music.
To "ham it up" is to do something ridiculous as to make people laugh.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a wound or sore with at least some abrasion, not just a bruise.

table.name: mem
table.column: For the plural, {-mey:n} is used even if the scab is still attached.
When it was first revealed, the {DIr:sen:nolink} was accidentally dropped. This was corrected in the Q & A session.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a two-syllable verb, and it's slang.
This was confirmed intransitive during the Q & A session.

table.name: mem
table.column: A teacher held in high esteem might be called a {ghojmoHwI' Han:n@@ghojmoHwI':n, Han:v}.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to a biological unit.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word does not appear in canon, but is an obvious construction based on {HapQeD:n:nolink}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word has a negative connotation in Klingon culture.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: This word has a negative connotation in Klingon culture.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: This literally means "perform surgery on" ({Haq:v:1}) and is used only if the tinkerer really knows what they're doing.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a doctor (see {Qel:n:1h}) who performs surgery (see {Haq:v:1}).[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: Marc Okrand decided to put this word into {TKD:src} because he thought artificial sweetener would be something that would be around in the future.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column:
In ascending order of ferocity, the verbs used to describe military confrontations are: {Qor:v}, {tlhaS:v}, {vay:v}, {lul:v}, {Hargh:v:nolink}.
This verb would be reserved only for situations approaching Armageddon.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to something like a medical condition that affects someone mentally or physically.
The Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 was authored by Senator Tom Harkin.

table.name: mem
table.column: "Over the Rainbow" was composed by Harold Arlen and its lyrics were written by E.Y. Harburg.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is used not only for animals. It can also be used for the sound an old door or a wooden chest makes when you open it, if it's a sort of high pitch.

table.name: mem
table.column: Note that {jIH:n:2} refers to the device, while {HaSta:n:nolink} refers to the visual information displayed on it. Also contrast this with {wIy:n}, which can also be displayed on a {jIH:n:2}.
Interesting coincidence: in the Spanish phrase "Hasta la vista" ("see you later"), "la vista" means "the view".

table.name: mem
table.column:
Maltz had a hunch this was shortened at some point from {HaSta 'ay':n@@HaSta:n, 'ay':n}, but that may be a folk etymology.[1]
This resembles the actual etymology of "pixel", which is shortened from "picture element".

table.name: mem
table.column: In slang, stolen goods are said to be "hot".

table.name: mem
table.column: For "random" in the sense of numbers, as when throwing dice, use {'al:v:2} instead.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a controlled roll. If a person is rolling haphazardly, the verb to use is {ron:v:1}. If someone is rolling down a hill (like a log), see {tetlh:v}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is typically round (so it could be a {'Ib rutlh:n@@'Ib:n, rutlh:v}) and portable (so it's not a {qegh:n}).[1]
Hyacinth Bucket is a character on the British sitcom "Keeping Up Appearances" (who insists that her surname is to be pronounced "bouquet").

table.name: mem
table.column:
To challenge someone to a duel, say {qablIj HI'ang!:sen} (This is often shortened to {HI'ang!:sen:nolink}) It is said of the party issuing the challenge that {qabDaj 'ang:sen@@qab:n, -Daj:n, 'ang:v} "he/she shows his/her face". The act of issuing the challenge is {poQ:v}, which is short for {qab legh 'e' poQ:sen@@qab:n, legh:v, 'e':n, poQ:v} "He/she demands to see a face". Hitting one's adversary with the back of the hand ({chap:n}) while issuing the challenge is to demand a duel to the death ({Hay'chu':v}).[2]
To agree to the duel, say {vISo'be':sen@@vI-:v, So':v:1, -be':v} "I don't hide it" (or the longer {qabwIj vISo'be':sen} "I don't hide my face"). The challenged party is then said to {'angchu':sen@@'ang:v, -chu':v} (short for {qab 'angchu':sen@@qab:n, 'ang:v, -chu':v}). One accepts a challenge ({qab 'ang:sen@@qab:n, 'ang:v}) in order to prove one's honor ({quv tob:sen@@quv:n, tob:v}).[2]
▶ {Hay' chaH.:sen:nolink} "They duel."[2] ▶ {Hay'chuq.:sen:nolink} "They duel one another."[2] ▶ {'avwI' Hay' yaS.:sen:nolink} "The officer duels the guard."[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is just the verb {Hay':v} with the suffix {-chu':v}. From the Klingon point of view, to duel perfectly is to duel to the death.[1]
▶ {Hay'chu' chaH.:sen:nolink} "They duel to the death."[1] ▶ {Hay'chuqchu'.:sen:nolink} "They duel one another to the death."[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: For different ways in which meat may be prepared, see {wamwI' Ha'DIbaH:n}, {voDleH Ha'DIbaH:n}, and {qeyvaq Ha'DIbaH:n}.

A lip movement match for "animal".
This was defined as "animal" in {TKD:src}, but as "meat, animal" in {TKDA:src}.

table.name: mem
table.column: Do not kill an animal unless you intend to eat it.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is what Klingons would call the Terran food.

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to the little piece of metal that holds sheets of paper together.
Marc Okrand has said that this word has a somewhat complicated pun, and it's not related to the Biblical Noah.

table.name: mem
table.column:
The object of {vev:v} is {Ha'on:n}. The papers stapled together are the object of {rar:v}.[1]
To use such a device, one may {qIp:v}, {'uy:v}, or {ngaH:v} it, depending on the particular device.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: In ancient times, this supported a sword. Now it is symbolic of one's {tuq:n}.

▶ {qorDu'Daj tuq 'oS Ha'quj'e' tuQbogh wo'rIv. tuQtaHvIS Hem. ghaHvaD quHDaj qawmoH.:sen:nolink} "The sash that Worf wears is a symbol of his family's house. He wears it proudly as a reminder of his heritage."[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: The expression {Ha'qujlIj nge':sen:nolink} "take away your sash" means "wound your pride".

table.name: mem
table.column:
This word can only refer to a physical route, and not to a spiritual or metaphorical route. "The Klingon Way", for example, is {tlhIngan tIgh:n:nolink}.
A physical path (which one can see and walk) on would be a {taw:n}.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {Ha'DIbaH DaSop 'e' DaHechbe'chugh yIHoHQo'.:sen} ▶ {Hem tlhIngan Segh 'ej maHemtaH 'e' wIHech.:sen}

table.name: mem
table.column:
"Head" off.
This word is listed among other militaristic terminology in the body of {KGT:src} on p.48.

table.name: mem
table.column: retreat perfectly, make a full withdrawal

This is just the verb {HeD:v} with the suffix {-chu':v}. While the suffix {-chu':v} is used with some verbs of fighting to imply that the fight results in death (see {Suvchu':v} and {Hay'chu':v}), there is no such implication with {HeDchu':v:nolink}. Though death may occur as part of the retreat, it is not necessarily implied.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: The fact that {yIn:v} can be used transitively suggests that {Hegh:v:nolink} can be too.

table.name: mem
mem
table.column: ▶ {Hegh Duj DatIj 'ej ghe'torDaq Duqeng.:sen:nolink} "Barge of the Dead ferries you to Gre'thor!"

table.name: mem
table.column: A fool's only achievement is death.

table.name: mem
table.column: This may also be written as {Heghba':n:nolink}.
It is written {Heghba':n:nolink} in the novel "Sarek".

table.name: mem
table.column: When a warrior dies, his spirit escapes.
The verb {nargh:v:2} means "escape", but it (or a phonetically identical word) also means "appear" (see {nargh:v:1}).

table.name: mem
table.column: Death is an experience best shared.
A version of this phrase with the typo {QaQpu':sen:nolink} (instead of {QaQqu':sen:nolink}) seems to have propagated online.

table.name: mem
table.column: It is a good day to die.

table.name: mem
table.column: The definition in {TKD:src} only says "be fatal", but it's clear that the verb takes an object since it is formed using {-moH:v}.

table.name: mem
table.column: See under {Hegh bey:n} for a description of this ritual.

table.name: mem
table.column: In {TNK:src}, {bIQ'a' HeH:n} is used to translate "beach". In the {paq'batlh:src}, {ngeng HeH:n} is used to translate "lakeshore".

table.name: mem
table.column: This is an admirable trait and does not carry connotations of arrogance, for which see {nguq:v}.

table.name: mem
table.column: Klingons are a proud race, and we intend to go on being proud.

table.name: mem
table.column: This means "experienced" in the sense of involvement in, exposure to, familiarity with, or hands-on dealing with a given area of knowledge or type of skill.[1]
A reference to The Jimi Hendrix Experience and its debut studio album "Are You Experienced".

table.name: mem
table.column: For the verb "whip", make use of {Qach:v}.[1]
One evades ({jun:v}) this if one is experienced ({Hen:v}).

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the name of a character from a play by {wIlyam SeQpIr:n:name}, and also the name of the play itself.

table.name: mem
table.column: finger (holes, strings of instrument) to vary sound

This word is applied to {SuSDeq:n} and {HurDagh:n}.[1]
See under {nItlh:n} for the verbs associated with each of the fingers.

table.name: mem
table.column:
This was defined as "hail" among other weather words. The "weather" clarification was added to distinguish it from the communication sense of "hail" ({rI':v}).
"Heck" is a euphemism for "hell", which sounds like "hail".

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {qarDaSQa'Daq ruDelya' rop'a' Hergh qengbogh yo' Dabot.:sen:nolink} "Intercept Rudellian plague relief convoy to Cardassian Union."[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: bird with a long neck and long legs
The original request behind this word was to translate "flamingo". The heron and the ibis are also birds with a long neck and long legs.

table.name: mem
table.column: R. Hess was a famous war criminal.

table.name: mem
table.column: There is an idiom, {tam; Hew rur}.

table.name: mem
table.column: battle or fight against one's own group
This verb indicates fighting against one's own group, and not the supposed enemy.[1]
This may have been a back-fit for a mispronunciation of {Hegh:v}.

table.name: mem
table.column: The components of an atom may include {yomIj:n}, {valtIn:n}, and {tem:n}.
The Atomium is a famous building in Heysel, Brussels.

table.name: mem
table.column: The Motion Picture Production Code, popularly known as the Hays Code, was a set of guidelines for the self-censorship of movie content.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word refers to the emission of odor. It does not have the idiomatic sense of "be very bad" as the word "stink" does in English.

table.name: mem
table.column:
"Hidrosis".
This was explicitly noted not to take an object.

table.name: mem
table.column:
This literally means "Come towards me!"
Watch Gowron say this: {YouTube video:url:http://youtu.be/Wq5mvIWRSKc}

table.name: mem
table.column: {HIj:v:nolink} is used for transporting goods, whereas it seems that {lup:v} is used for transporting people.

▶ {yIHmey DaHIj'a'? ghobe', yIHmey vIHIjbe'.:sen@@yIH:n, -mey:n, Da-:v, HIj:v, -'a':v, ghobe':excl, yIH:n, -mey:n, vI-:v, HIj:v, -be':v} "Are you transporting tribbles? No. I'm not transporting tribbles."[2] ▶ {HIjmeH 'ap:n}

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the fee paid when bringing certain commodities into a jurisdiction.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column:
This is the positive answer to a yes/no question (see {-'a':v}). Unlike the English word "yes", it is not used as a stand-alone exclamation indicating insight, joy, and so on (for which see {toH:excl} and {Qapla'!:sen}). For an exclamation indicating compliance, such as in response to a command, see {lu':excl}.
Watch Gowron say this: {YouTube video:url:http://youtu.be/KArQlviVXMk}
Looks like a combination of the Japanese and German affirmative answers ("hai" and "ja").

table.name: mem
table.column: The object of this verb is the person whose presence is being announced. It might be used to indicate why someone is knocking on a door.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is singular. {HIl'aDmey:n@@HIl'aD:n, -mey:n} would mean several sets of instructions.

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to the clothing worn in battle.
In English slang, "hip" means fashionable in the context of clothing.

table.name: mem
mem
table.column: To find ale, go into a bar.

table.name: mem
table.column: This describes how a stamp is stuck to an envelope or a wad of spit is stuck to the wall.
This was defined as "be stuck" with an explanation, along with a bunch of other words which can be translated into various senses of "be stuck" in English.

table.name: mem
table.column: This means to speak to oneself, internally (and not aloud). It's used like a verb of speaking (see {jatlh:v}).[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: This line was spoken in Klingon but was not subtitled.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is known as a tourist drink.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word is listed among other militaristic terminology in the body of {KGT:src} on p.48.

table.name: mem
table.column: A ship cloaks in order to attack.

table.name: mem
table.column: When used with the verb {HIv:v}, the suffix {-neS:v:suff} indicates that suicide is part of the plan of attack.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: A piano (which is not a Klingon instrument) in a piano bar (where patrons are sometimes encouraged to drink and sing) is sometimes called this.[1]

Maltz said that he wasn't aware of this word being used for pianos elsewhere, but it might be.[1]
Steinway ({HIvje':n} + {He:n}) is a company which produces pianos.

table.name: mem
table.column: In the {paq'batlh:n}, {molor:n:name} is referred to as a {HI''a':n:nolink} "tyrant" throughout.

table.name: mem
table.column:
{HItoy'.:sen:nolink}
There's no evidence that {tuy:n:nolink} exists as an independent word or component.

table.name: mem
table.column:
If {Hoch:n:nolink} is followed by a noun which is explicitly plural, it means "all the X's", taken collectively. If the following noun is not explicitly plural, then it means "each X", considered individually.[2]
If {Hoch:n:nolink} follows a noun, it means "all of X".[4] Note that this is different from {naQ:v} following a noun, which means "a complete X".
This was defined as "everyone, all, everything" in {TKD:src}. The meaning "each" was added based on an article in {HolQeD:src}.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: end, last item in a list

The first item in a list of words (for example) would be {mu' wa'DIch:n@@mu':n, wa'DIch:n}, while one could say {mu' HochDIch:n@@mu':n, HochDIch:n} for the last word in the list, or use a special term for the end of a list, {natlIS:n}.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: The sentence from {SkyBox 15:src} seems to have the {wa'DIch:n} in the wrong place. Also, the second occurrence of {vatlh DIS poH:n} is missing a space.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is an emphatic alternative for {reH:adv}.
▶ {Hochlogh no' yIquvmoH.:sen:nolink} "Always honor your ancestors", literally, "All times honor your ancestors".

table.name: mem
table.column: The example sentence was MO's reply to the interviewer who asked him to choose his favourite Star Trek technology. He chose the transporter beam ({jol:n}).
▶ {Hoch Holmey mughwI' vIwIv 'e' DapIH'a'?:sen@@Hoch Holmey mughwI':n, vI-:v, wIv:v, 'e':n, Da-:v, pIH:v:1, -'a':v} "Did you expect me to choose the Universal Translator?"

table.name: mem
table.column: Pity the warrior who slays all his foes.

This is a famous line from the poem {lu qeng:n:name,nolink} by G'trok. The idiomatic expression {Hoch jaghpu'Daj HoHpu':sen:nolink} "He/she has killed all his/her enemies" means that a person leads a meaningless, empty life, one lacking any challenge.

table.name: mem
table.column: This idiomatic expression, which is based on the homophony of the words {nuH:n:1} and {nuH:n:2}, means "to consider every possibility" or "to consider every option".
▶ {Hoch nuH yIqel!:sen:nolink} "Consider every possibility!" ▶ {Hoch nuH Daqel'a'?:sen:nolink} "Did you consider every option?"

table.name: mem
table.column: Eat everything or you will die without honor.
This is roughly like saying, "Eat, eat!"
QI'lop, Eat everything or you will die without honour.

table.name: mem
table.column: This means "capture all opportunities" (taken collectively) and not "capture each opportunity" (considered individually).[2]

table.name: mem
table.column:
This is the 5th rank of {yaS:n}.[2]
Watch Gowron say this: {YouTube video:url:http://youtu.be/9CTfqKn383I}

table.name: mem
table.column:
The Klingon week has six days, which are: ▶ {DaSjaj:n} "Monday" ▶ {povjaj:n} "Tuesday" ▶ {ghItlhjaj:n} "Wednesday" ▶ {loghjaj:n} "Thursday" ▶ {buqjaj:n} "Friday" ▶ {lojmItjaj:n} or {ghInjaj:n} "Saturday"
If an alien calendar contains more than six days, additional days are numbered beginning with {wa':n:num}. Thus, "Sunday" would be {jaj wa':n}. The eighth day of the week on {lenmaq:n}, which uses an eight-day week, is called {jaj cha':n:nolink}, and so on.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is short for {romuluSngan Sambogh 'ej HoHbogh nejwI':n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is simply the verb {HoH:v} with the suffix {-'egh:v}.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: teen, teenager, adolescent, youth, young adult
A slang term for this is {yaD:n:3}.
{Hoj:v} means "be cautious". Since teenagers are known for not being cautious, the {nIy:sen:nolink} might be a negation word (possibly "nie" from German).

table.name: mem
table.column:
In Klingon, names of languages are formed by attaching {Hol:n:nolink} to an identifier for the language. For example, "Klingon" (the language) is {tlhIngan Hol:n}, and {tlhIngan:n} by itself does not refer to the language, but to a person or people.
The identifier is usually a country, region, or political unit of some kind. For example, Federation Standard (i.e., "English") is {DIvI' Hol:n}. {tlhIngan Hol:n:nolink} is actually a shortened form of {tlhIngan wo' Hol:n:nolink}.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This term is used by younger Klingons to refer to the way they prefer to speak.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is also the name of the journal of the {tlhIngan Hol yejHaD:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column:
This term does not appear in canon, but is an obvious construction from {HolQeD:n}. (It was revealed at {Saarbrücken qepHom'a' 2019:src} that if a {QeD:n:nolink} exists, then there is generally a corresponding {tej:n:nolink}.)
{Holtej:n:name,nolink} is also the Klingon name of linguist and Klingonist d'Armond Speers.

table.name: mem
table.column: weakling, runt, scrawny one, skinny one

table.name: mem
table.column: Due to the homophony with {Hom:n:2}, to point one's second toe at someone (typically an opponent or an enemy), while the other toes point downwards, is considered an insulting gesture. It signifies that one considers the other person to be weak.
▶ {jaghwI'Daq jIHom.:sen:nolink} "I claim my enemy is unworthy or weak."

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to a type of dense, non-vascular tissue, usually found at the end of joints, the rib cage, the ear, the nose, and between intervertebral disks. It is an ingredient of {ngat:n:2}.
It's not clear if {HomHap:n:nolink} exists as an independent word.

table.name: mem
table.column: This verb can take {'e':n:pro} as its object.[2]
▶ {tlhIngan Hol Dajatlh 'e' vIHon.:sen:nolink} "I doubt that you speak Klingon."[2]

table.name: mem
table.column:
This verb is used in the same way as {Sum:v} (it involves the concept of deixis).[2]
In Klingon, "deep space" is called {logh Hop:n}, literally, "far space".[3]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is used for pulling a child's wagon (by its handle) or for a train engine to pull the train along or to pull an electrical plug out of the wall.[1] For pulling a bowstring or tugging at something without moving (dragging) it, see {Hur:v}. For a sudden pull, see {luH:v:1}.

table.name: mem
table.column: be honored falsely, be falsely honorable

Deception is implied by the use of this verb.
This word is used in places where {quv:v} might be used, but when the honor was discovered to be illegitimate. For exampe, a {Duy quv:n:nolink} who turns out to be a spy would be called a {Duy HoQ:n:nolink}.
It differs from {quvHa':v} in that it indicates that one has demanded respect which is unearned or undeserved. A warrior who shows cowardice in battle is a {SuvwI' quvHa':n:nolink}. One who hides his cowardice, is awarded for valor (i.e., becomes known as a {SuvwI' quv:n:nolink}), and is subsequently discovered to be a fraud, is a {SuvwI' HoQ:n:nolink}.
Do not use this word lightly as it has very bad connotations in Klingon society.
be honoured falsely, be falsely honourable

table.name: mem
table.column:
There is an idiom, {HoS; 'Iw rur:sen@@HoS:v, 'Iw:n, rur:v}.
This verb is also used for regular polygons and polyhedra.[2]
▶ {vagh reD mey' HoS:n@@vagh reD mey':n, HoS:v} "regular pentagon"[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: "Horse" power. The character of Eric "Hoss" Cartwright on the TV show "Bonanza" has a reputation for being strong.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a device which changes energy from one form to another.

table.name: mem
table.column: You are a total waste of good energy!

table.name: mem
table.column: {pIraqSIS:n} is an important Klingon energy facility.
▶ {pIraqSIS HoS waw' ghajlu'chugh, loSlogh boq'egh mI' naghmey mI'; chen qav'ap.:sen:nolink} "If Praxis Energy Facility is owned, rent is 4 times amount shown on dice."

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to the magnitude of a wave (such as an electromagnetic wave). This literally means "strength" (see {HoS:n:1}).

table.name: mem
table.column: It's not clear if this word is grammatically singular or plural. One energy being is a {HoS Dep:n@@HoS:n:1, Dep:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: The term {HoS Hal:n:nolink} (with a space) has also appeared in canon. See the example under {nISwI' beH:n}.

▶ {HoSHal ghajchugh vay', mI' naghmey tIronmoH. wa'maHlogh boq'egh mI' naghmey; chen qav'ap. ghajwI'vaD qav'ap yIDIl.:sen:nolink} "If [energy source is] owned, throw dice and pay owner a total ten times amount shown."

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to a type of hard igneous rock, which is very common in oceanic crust.
Basalt comes from an ancient Greek word meaning "touchstone" ({Hot:v} + {nagh:n}).

table.name: mem
table.column: The homophonous {Hotlh:v:2} suggests that this verb refers to the combined act of both capturing and displaying an image.

table.name: mem
table.column: The homophonous {Hotlh:v:1} suggests that this verb refers to the combined act of both capturing and displaying an image.

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to an astronomical body, and not to the geometric figure, for which see {DujtlhuQ:n}.
This is defined in {TKD:src} only as "star". The "astronomy" part was added for clarification.

table.name: mem
table.column: Hov ghajbe'bogh ram rur pegh ghajbe'bogh jaj.
A day without secrets is like a night without stars.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a symbolic representation of the constellation {ghochwI':n}.
This was only spoken on {KCD:src}. The written form later appeared in the {Saarbrücken qepHom'a' 2019:src} booklet.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the name of a popular television franchise. It includes the following series: ▶ The Original Series ▶ The Animated Series ▶ The Next Generation ({puq poH veb:n}) ▶ Deep Space Nine ({logh Hop Hut tengchaH:n}) ▶ Voyager ({vo'yajer:n:name}) ▶ Enterprise ({'entepray':n:name}) ▶ Discovery ({DISqa'vI'rIy:n:name})

table.name: mem
table.column: This is an out-of-universe phrase that doesn't come from Klingon culture.[2]
It really ought to be {Hov leng cham:n:nolink}, but canon is canon.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is an idiom meaning "I trust you" or "I know you will honor your word".

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {tera' poH jaj wa', jar wa', jaj loSDIch, DIS wa'-Hut-Hut-chorgh. HovpoHvetlh latlh nab yIHutlh.:sen:nolink} "Save this Stardate: Sunday, January 4, 1998"[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the everyday term. There is a more technical term, but Maltz didn't remember what it was.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the technical or scientific term, but another way of referring to this process is {mutchoH:n}.[1]
In {TNG - Evolution:src}, a computer malfunction causes the song "The Stars and Stripes Forever" ({Hov:n}, {'ejvoH:n}) to be played.

table.name: mem
table.column: be refined, be fancy, be sophisticated (pertaining to culture)
"Hoity-toity". Also comedic inversion of "hoi polloi", meaning "the common people".

table.name: mem
table.column: Aside from its literal meaning as a body part, this word can also be used to refer to the "teeth" on a cogwheel or sprocket wheel (see {Ho':n:3}).

table.name: mem
table.column: idol, someone worthy of emulation, something deserving of respect

This word follows the grammatical rules appropriate to its literal meaning (see {Ho':n:1}). It takes the plural suffix {-Du':n:suff} and possessive suffixes such as {-wIj:n:suff}, even when it refers to a person or people.[1, p.152]
This is defined in the {KGT:src} word list only as "idol". The expanded definition above is from p.152.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word takes the plural suffix {-Du':n:suff}, even though it's not a body part.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to the serrated blade found on a {qutluch:n}.[1, p.61]

table.name: mem
table.column: You have some stuffed to'baj leg in your teeth.

table.name: mem
table.column: There is a Klingon idiom, {Sagh; Ho''oy' rur@@Sagh:v, Ho''oy':n, rur:v}.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: Note that this refers to a "system" in the sense of a way of doing something. For a physical (or physical-like) system, see {pat:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: Hou Yi (后羿) is an archer in Chinese mythology.

table.name: mem
table.column: Dr. Seuss wrote "If I Ran the Zoo" and "Horton Hears a Who!"

table.name: mem
table.column: This word is listed among other militaristic terminology in the body of {KGT:src} on p.48.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word is listed among other militaristic terminology in the body of {KGT:src} on p.48.

table.name: mem
table.column: This does not appear in {TKDA:src} by itself, but only as part of {tlhIngan Hubbeq:n:nolink}.

table.name: mem
table.column: When used with the verb {Hub:v}, the suffix {-neS:v:suff} indicates that suicide is part of the defense plan.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {Quj wa'DIch MONOPOLY Huch nav qa' tlhIngan QaS:sen:nolink} "Klingon forces replace original MONOPOLY bills"[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This literally means "money plate". It is often, but not always, followed by {-Hom:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: Don't trust Ferengi who give back money.
There is a grammatical error with this sentence. It should be {tIvoqQo':sen@@tI-:v, voq:v, -Qo':v} rather than {yIvoqQo':sen:nolink}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This literally means "money plates". It is often, but not always, followed by {-Hom:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word has no (known) non-slang counterpart.
Presumably, an economist would be a {Huchtej:n@@Huch:n, tej:n}, but this word has never appeared in canon.

table.name: mem
table.column: Mt. Hood is the name of a mountain in northern Oregon.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the name of a geographic feature between {SaqSub:n} and {QIStaq:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a district inside {Sa'Qej Sep:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is typically used for storing things, unlike a {raywal:n} which is intended to be used by people, although there is overlap between them.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: The name of a mountainous planet.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is used to describe waves or curves and is also used in trigonometry.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {qaStaHvIS wa' ram loS SaD Hugh SIjlaH qetbogh loD.:sen}

table.name: mem
table.column:
Depending on the context, this word may also be glossed as "bile" or "gall".
Watch Gowron say this: {YouTube video:url:http://youtu.be/tAK-hgXMH-M}

table.name: mem
table.column: One first charges up ({Huj:v:2,nolink}) a device before energizing ({rIH:v}) it.

table.name: mem
table.column: Note that a human ({Human:n:nolink}) is a member of the indigenous sentient species of Earth ({tera':n:place}), whereas Terran ({tera'ngan:n}) refers to any inhabitant of the planet.

table.name: mem
table.column: a creature like a {ghargh:n}, but with lots of wiggly legs

table.name: mem
table.column: This animal is known for its speed.
▶ {nom leng Hun nom lengqu' lut:sen:nolink} "Stories travel faster than a Khrun"[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a tax paid to the government when either buying or selling something. This would also be used for "sales tax" or VAT (value-added tax) if there were no reason to make a further distinction.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: This verb developed from {HurwI':n}. Applied to a {HurwI':n:nolink}, this refers to the act of pulling back the string of the bow (before releasing and launching the arrow). In other contexts, it may refer to pulling the handle on a door to open or close the door or to pulling on someone's suspenders.[1] For pulling involving movement of the thing being pulled, see {Hoq:v}. For a sudden pull, see {luH:v:1}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This isn't a Klingon device, but Klingons have learned about it. Originally, it was called a {HurDagh chuHwI':n} by analogy, but over time this got shortened to {HurwI':n:nolink}. From this, a new verb {Hur:v} developed. Some Klingons refer to a bow as a {Ho'yI':n}.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column:
This is the general term for a musical instrument with strings ({SIrgh:n}), which one may either pluck ({pang:v}) or strum ({yach:v:2}). To vary the sound, one "fingers" ({Heng:v}) the strings (touch them at different points while plucking or strumming).[1]
Types of {HurDagh:n:nolink} include the {Supghew:n} (small), the {leSpal:n} (medium), and the {tIngDagh:n} (large).
A {HurDagh:n:nolink} is not generally played with a bow, but a {ngItHel:n} may be plucked, strummed, or bowed.
The "hurdy gurdy" is a type of stringed instrument.

table.name: mem
table.column: The Klingon Empire has ships which could both fly and submerge underwater. Whether this refers specifically to a submarine or a blimp depends on context. To differentiate them, a submarine would be a {bIQ Hurgh Duj:n@@bIQ:n, Hurgh Duj:n} and a blimp would be a {muD Hurgh Duj:n@@muD:n:1, Hurgh Duj:n}.[1] A {Hurgh Duj:n:nolink} typically has a motor for propulsion.[2]
This word and information about it were revealed in conversation during the {qepHom:src}.

table.name: mem
table.column: There is an idiom, {wIH; Hur'Iqngan rur@@wIH:v, Hur'Iqngan:n, rur:v}.

table.name: mem
table.column:
This is used, for example, for hanging a coat on a hook or clothes on a clothesline. But it's not used for a spider dangling from a silk thread or a pair of shoes dangling by their laces from an overhead power line, which is {tlhep:v}.
This is not used to mean "execute by hanging", which is {jIb:v}.
It's confirmed this takes an object.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This word also has a slang meaning (see {HutmaH:n:2}).

table.name: mem
table.column: This is used in the slang expression {HutmaH chav:sen@@HutmaH:n:2, chav:v} "achieve 90" (see {ghuch:v}). Maltz had never heard anyone say {'ebraH chav:sen@@'ebraH:n, chav:v}, mixing the standard word together with the slang.[1]
The movie "Long Shot" (2019) has a controversial sex scene which lasted for 90 seconds.

table.name: mem
table.column: too many people or things in a place at once
This term is used as a play on words, substituting for the curse {Qu'vatlh:excl} in situations where it is appropriate.
This word was disclosed during a congested drive on Interstate 95 (i.e., {Hut:n}, {vagh:n:1,num}).

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to a small, usually metal, spike typically used for fastening wood.
This is a reference to the industrial rock band "Nine Inch Nails".

table.name: mem
table.column: This literally means "long nail", and refers to the sticks used in some forms of weaving (see {nIq:v}).

table.name: mem
table.column: The "Phillips-head" screw and screwdriver are named for Henry F. Phillips.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a unit of information in computer science.
John Hutton played Claude Shannon in the 2018 film "The Bit Player".

table.name: mem
table.column: lack, be without, to not have

table.name: mem
table.column: This can be used both for singing without words and for the sound a (not huge) engine makes. It's also used for the sound of a cat (purr).

table.name: mem
table.column: Huy Fong Foods is a hot sauce company, whose most popular product is sriracha sauce.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a slang use of {Huy:v:2} to mean {qIS:v}.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column:
There is an idiom, {val; Huy' rur@@val:v, Huy':n, rur:v}.[2]
Klingons generally can't raise their eyebrows (other than those suffering from the aftereffects of the Augment crisis). Nevertheless, there are a couple of ways to describe this facial movement commonly seen in other species. The most frequently heard involves the verb {wanHa':v} (or, more commonly, {wanHa'moH:v@@wanHa':v, -moH:v}). Other verbs are also sometimes used, such as {'ob:v} ({'obmoH:v@@'ob:v, -moH:v}) or {SIH:v} ({SIHmoH:v@@SIH:v, -moH:v}).[3]

table.name: mem
table.column: This word seems to be composed of {Huy':n} and {Dung:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: The fact that this is homophonous with {Hu':v} may have to do with how many times one has gotten up (from sleep) since the day in question. Note that {leS:n:nolink} is also homophonous with {leS:v}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a filler word. It's sometimes {Hu'mI:sen:nolink} and sometimes just {Hu:sen:nolink}. Another pause vocalization is just a low-toned {ghghgh:sen:nolink}.[1]
The character Ralph Kramden on the TV show "The Honeymooners" would say this when at a loss for words.
